linkedin_essay.text:
In a previous article History Future Now admitted defeat: climate change is happening and there is no viable political solution which will enable us to stop it from getting worse. Global average temperatures will rise beyond the 2 degrees that politicians have determined is the absolute maximum that it should be allowed to increase by. We need to stop worrying about how to prevent it from getting worse and start concentrating on what governments need to do to manage this new reality. In this article we will look at the impact of global and local food shortages, exacerbated by climate change, and how governments should respond. Since History Future Now is UK based, the article will have a UK focused slant. First, lets start with a basic understanding of the food situation we are in today and what we can expect over the next 25 years. The worldâ€™s population is now over 7.3 billion. It will be 10 billion in another two to three decades. In the meantime, our primary food production areas are in trouble. One third of global agriculture is irrigated using underground aquifer water, which is finite and will run out in 25 years . Soil quality is declining as it is depleted or concreted over in new urban developments. Fish stocks are 20% of what they were in the mid 1950s.
